javadoc:
The Application class provides a variety of static convenience methods for accessing Application elements that can be used once the {@link #initializeApplication} call has been made.

In order to initialize an application, an {@link ApplicationLayout} and an {@link ApplicationConfiguration} must be provided. The layout and configuration come in a variety of flavors, and are what makes the Application class usable across a range of tools.

Example use case: 

   ApplicationLayout layout = new GhidraApplicationLayout();
   ApplicationConfiguration configuration = new GhidraApplicationConfiguration();
   Application.initalizeApplication(layout, configuration);

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Creates a new application object.  Application is a singleton so this is private.

params.name: layout
params.comment: The application layout to be used by this application.

params.name: configuration
params.comment: The application configuration to be used by this application.

methods.name: initializeApplication
methods.comment:
Initializes the application.  The static methods of this class cannot be used until the
 application is initialized.

params.name: layout
params.comment: The application layout to be used by the application.

params.name: configuration
params.comment: The application configuration to be used by the application.

methods.javadoc:
Checks to see if the application has been initialized.
@return true if the application has been initialized; otherwise, false.
methods.name: isInitialized
methods.comment: Checks to see if the application has been initialized.

return.comment: true if the application has been initialized; otherwise, false.

methods.name: initializeLogging
methods.comment:
If the Application was previously initialized with logging disabled, this method
 may be used to perform delayed logging initialization.

params.name: logFile
params.comment:
application log file, if null the default application.log will be stored
 within the user's application settings directory

params.name: scriptLogFile
params.comment:
scripting log file, if null the default script.log will be stored
 within the user's application settings directory

methods.javadoc:
Returns the module root directory that contains the class that called this method.
@return the module root directory that contains the class that called this method.
methods.name: getMyModuleRootDirectory
methods.comment: Returns the module root directory that contains the class that called this method.

return.comment: the module root directory that contains the class that called this method.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the name of the application.
@return the name of the application.
methods.name: getName
methods.comment: Returns the name of the application.

return.comment: the name of the application.

methods.name: getApplicationProperty
methods.comment: Returns the value of the give application property name.

params.name: propertyName
params.comment: the name of the application property to retrieve.

return.comment: the value of the give application property name.

methods.javadoc:
Returns a list of the application root directories.  An application root directory is a
 directory containing one or more modules.  Applications support multiple application root
 directories so that it can contain modules that don't have a common file system root.  This
 is useful if the application contains modules from more than one source code repository.
 Application roots are returned in the order they appear in the classpath.
@return a list of root directories containing modules for this application.
methods.name: getApplicationRootDirectories
methods.comment:
Returns a list of the application root directories.  An application root directory is a
 directory containing one or more modules.  Applications support multiple application root
 directories so that it can contain modules that don't have a common file system root.  This
 is useful if the application contains modules from more than one source code repository.
 Application roots are returned in the order they appear in the classpath.

return.comment: a list of root directories containing modules for this application.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the application root directory. An application root directory is a directory containing one or more modules. In development mode there may be multiple application root directories, which can be retrieved via {@link #getApplicationRootDirectories()}.

In an installation of the application, there will only be one application root directory.

Note: Be sure you understand that there may be multiple application root directories in development mode. In general you should not be using this method for searching for files yourself, but instead using the various find* methods of this class. @return Returns the application root directory. @see #getApplicationRootDirectories()
methods.name: getApplicationRootDirectory
methods.comment:
Returns the application root directory.   An application root directory is a
 directory containing one or more modules.  In development mode there may be multiple 
 application root directories, which can be retrieved via 
 #getApplicationRootDirectories().
 
 In an installation of the application, there will only be one application root directory.
 
 Note:  Be sure you understand that there may be multiple application root
 directories in development mode.  In general you should not be using this method for 
 searching for files yourself, but instead using 
 the various find* methods of this class.

return.comment: Returns the application root directory.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the File containing the user configuration settings for this application.
@return the File containing the user configuration settings for this application.
methods.name: getUserSettingsDirectory
methods.comment: Returns the File containing the user configuration settings for this application.

return.comment: the File containing the user configuration settings for this application.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the temporary directory specific to the user and the application.
 Directory has name of <username>-<appname>
 This directory may be removed at system reboot or during periodic 
 system cleanup of unused temp files.
 This directory is specific to the application name but not the version.
 Resources stored within this directory should utilize some 
 form of access locking or unique naming.  Transient resources should be 
 deleted when no longer in use.
@return temp directory
methods.name: getUserTempDirectory
methods.comment:
Returns the temporary directory specific to the user and the application.
 Directory has name of username-appname
 This directory may be removed at system reboot or during periodic 
 system cleanup of unused temp files.
 This directory is specific to the application name but not the version.
 Resources stored within this directory should utilize some 
 form of access locking or unique naming.  Transient resources should be 
 deleted when no longer in use.

return.comment: temp directory

methods.javadoc:
Returns the cache directory specific to the user and the application.
 The intention is for directory contents to be preserved, however the 
 specific location is platform specific and contents may be removed when
 not in use and may in fact be the same directory the user temp directory.
 This directory is specific to the application name but not the version.
 Resources stored within this directory should utilize some 
 form of access locking and/or unique naming.
@return cache directory
methods.name: getUserCacheDirectory
methods.comment:
Returns the cache directory specific to the user and the application.
 The intention is for directory contents to be preserved, however the 
 specific location is platform specific and contents may be removed when
 not in use and may in fact be the same directory the user temp directory.
 This directory is specific to the application name but not the version.
 Resources stored within this directory should utilize some 
 form of access locking and/or unique naming.

return.comment: cache directory

methods.name: getModuleRootDirectories
methods.comment:
Returns a collection of all the module root directories. A module root directory is
 the top-level directory of a module.

return.comment: a collection of all the module root directories.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the installation directory.  In an installation, there is only one application root
 and its parent is the installation directory.  If not an installation, then this call doesn't
 really make sense, but it will return the parent of the first installation root.
@return
methods.name: getInstallationDirectory
methods.comment:
Returns the installation directory.  In an installation, there is only one application root
 and its parent is the installation directory.  If not an installation, then this call doesn't
 really make sense, but it will return the parent of the first installation root.

methods.name: getModuleRootDir
methods.comment: Return the module root directory for the module with the given name.

params.name: moduleName
params.comment: the name of the module.

return.comment: the module root directory for the module with the given name or null if not found.

methods.name: isTestBuild
methods.comment:
Returns true if this build was not built through the official build process, but instead
  was created using the "buildLocal" call.

return.comment: true if this build was not built using the official build process.

methods.javadoc:
Checks whether or not the application is in "single jar" mode.
@return true if the application is in "single jar" mode; otherwise, false.
methods.name: inSingleJarMode
methods.comment: Checks whether or not the application is in "single jar" mode.

return.comment: true if the application is in "single jar" mode; otherwise, false.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the version of this build.
@return the version of this build.
methods.name: getApplicationVersion
methods.comment: Returns the version of this build.

return.comment: the version of this build.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the date this build was created.
@return the date this build was created.
methods.name: getBuildDate
methods.comment: Returns the date this build was created.

return.comment: the date this build was created.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the release name for this build.
@return the application release name.
methods.name: getApplicationReleaseName
methods.comment: Returns the release name for this build.

return.comment: the application release name.

methods.name: getApplicationSourceRevisions
methods.comment:
Return the source repository revisions used in the build process
 or null if not applicable.

return.comment: source revision map or null if not applicable

methods.javadoc:
Returns a collection of module library directories. Library directories are optional for a module.
@return a collection of module library directories.
methods.name: getLibraryDirectories
methods.comment: Returns a collection of module library directories. Library directories are optional for a module.

return.comment: a collection of module library directories.

methods.name: findFilesByExtensionInApplication
methods.comment: Returns all files within any module's data directory that end with the given extension.

params.name: extension
params.comment: the extension of files to be found.

return.comment: all files within any module's data directory that end with the given extension.

methods.name: findDataFileInAnyModule
methods.comment: Finds the first file that exists with the relative path in any module.

params.name: relativePath
params.comment: the path from the module root

return.comment: the first file that exists with the relative path in any module.

methods.name: findFilesByExtensionInMyModule
methods.comment:
Returns a list of all files with the given extension that are located in the module
 of the calling class.

params.name: extension
params.comment: the filename extension for which to find file.s

return.comment:
a list of all files with the given extension that are located in the module
 of the calling class.

methods.name: findFilesByExtension
methods.comment: Returns a list of all files with the given extension that are located in the named module.

params.name: moduleName
params.comment: the name of the module for which to look for files with the given extension.

params.name: extension
params.comment: the filename extension for which to find file.s

return.comment: a list of all files with the given extension that are located in the named module.

methods.name: findModuleSubDirectories
methods.comment:
Returns a list of all directories in any module that have the given module relative path.  For
 example, a relative path of "foo/bar" will return all directories that are of the form
 /data/foo/bar

params.name: relativePath
params.comment: the module relative path to search for.

return.comment: a list of all directories in any module that have the given module relative path.

methods.name: getModuleDataSubDirectory
methods.comment: Returns the directory relative to the calling class's module's data directory.

params.name: relativePath
params.comment: the path relative the module's data directory

throws.comment: if the directory does not exist.
if an error occurred trying to access the directory.

methods.name: getModuleDataSubDirectory

Return the directory relative the the name module's data directory. (i.e. "/data" will
 be prepended to the given path)

params.name: moduleName
params.comment: the name of the module.

params.name: relativePath
params.comment: the path relative to the module's data directory.

throws.comment: if the directory does not exist
if an error occurred trying to access the directory.

methods.name: getModuleSubDirectory
methods.comment: Return the directory relative the the name module's directory.

params.name: moduleName
params.comment: the name of the module.

params.name: relativePath
params.comment: the path relative to the module's root directory.

throws.comment: if the directory does not exist
if an error occurred trying to access the directory.

methods.name: getModuleDataFile
methods.comment: Returns the file relative to the calling class's module's data directory

params.name: relativeDataPath

throws.comment: if the file or module does not exist.

methods.name: getModuleDataFile
methods.comment:
Returns the file relative to the named module's data directory. (i.e. "data/" will
 be prepended to the give path)

params.name: moduleName
params.comment: the name of the module.

params.name: relativeDataPath
params.comment: the path relative to the module's data directory.

throws.comment: if the file does not exist.

methods.name: getModuleFile
methods.comment: Returns the file relative to the named module's directory.

params.name: moduleName
params.comment: the name of the module.

throws.comment: if the file does not exist.

methods.name: getOSFile
methods.comment: Returns the OS specific file within the given module with the given name.

params.name: moduleName
params.comment: the name of the module

params.name: exactFilename
params.comment: the name of the OS file within the module.

throws.comment: if the file does not exist.

methods.name: getOSFile
methods.comment: Returns the OS specific file in the calling class's module.

params.name: exactFilename

name: Application
